title: Between 20 September 2019 and 6 December 2019, will the closing price for Brent crude oil exceed $75.00, according to Bloomberg?
preds: The EIA lowered its forecasts for WTI and Brent early September. For 2020 as well.

Global trade and manufacturing demand will not rise in this period. Saudi arabia will keep supply high and Iran has taken its shot at “safely” disrupting supply. All oil producers need the money so they keep pumping. Big unknown remains Mideast conflict that drags others in.

Given current level of Brent crude price, percentage price change needs to be 16.8% over next 2 weeks for price to exceed US$75.  Historically, such a 2-week price change happened once in 348 observations over the past 10 years.  This gives a probability of 0.3%.  Very closed to zero, but non-zero still.  Sticking with 1%.
Between 20 September 2019 and 6 December 2019, will the closing price for Brent crude oil exceed $75.00, according to Bloomberg?

I’m at 1% only for black swan kind of event. 
From the Economist:
“The latest oil outlook published by the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries does not make for cheery reading. The group lowered its forecast for oil demand as fears mount that a recession will reduce the need for it. That comes as OPEC has struggled to maintain a high oil price. In December last year OPEC and its allies, as well as Russia, agreed to cut output by 1.2m barrels a day to support the price of crude. Yet prices have slumped from almost $75 in April to around $60. A drone attack in September on Saudi Arabia’s biggest processing facility pushed prices up, but only temporarily. Little wonder that OPEC’s chief, Mohammad Barkindo, said in October that the club and its allies may consider deeper cuts to oil production when they meet in Vienna in December. After his comments, oil prices ticked up. However, much depends on the outcome of trade talks between China and America.”

Increasing from 2% to 5%, given recent news that Saudi Arabia's national oil company, Saudi Aramco, is in the process of launching its initial public offering [1,2, 3]. I think this slightly raises the possibility of another attack by Iran on Saudi Aramco's oil infrastructure - and another such attack would make it extremely likely that Brent crude will exceed $75. Brent crude oil prices have been climbing.  However, World economic growth has been declining.
I think I might have over-priced the geo-political risk. Global growth seems to be the primary factor affecting crude prices. Adjusting down.

I reduced my forecast to 0% on the understanding that the question is asking for the "average" closing price between Sep 20 and Dec 6.  If the question is asking for at any day before Dec 6, there is still a small chance (still <5%) that the price may exceed $75/bbl but only in response to another major geopolitical event.
A war would have to break out in Europe or the middle eastern countries for Brent to rise significantly
Checked my instincts using historic data and found about a 1% chance of this occurring.
Very unlikely but not impossible - reaffirming 1%
The recent attack on  Saudi Arabia still hasn't been avenged.  Retribution is coming. During the impeachment hearings will be a good time.
Accounting for the prob of the price + likelihood of any unexpected disruption
It won't reach $75 in normal trading, but if there is a supply disruption it could easily reach $75, so it's just the probability of disruption.
Updating with current price and passing of time.

End of 2014 the price fell quickly from $113 down to $28 where it bottomed at the beginning of 2016 - since 2016 the price has only exceeded $75 a few times [all in 2018]  Trends = down 25% over ten years - demand is being impacted by use of renewables / alternatives - shift to EV and all the other climate related changes that are spreading across economies 
There are geopolitical factors to consider - [recent bombing of Saudi infrastructure - issues with Iran]  the $ price experienced short term volatility but has since remained within a reasonably tight range 
Downtrend to continue unless something out of the ordinary were to occur
Lowering slightly for now. Generally need to see some better economic news, forecasts... https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-14/oil-holds-near-lows-as-u-s-china-trade-deal-hopes-evaporate
The glut of oil coming out of the US and the slowing world economy prevent oil from reaching such price levels.
Maybe there will be a war to drive it up, other than that prob not

There’s potential conflict with iran but rel with saudi is not strained. With the climate movements happening demand is going down, so if supply isnt affected will likely not go up. Looking at past years the trend seems to be decreasing prices towards the end of the years.
OPEC cut oil demand growth forecast once more, this time 40k b/d from September's forecast. Seems less likely that Brent crude oil will exceed $75.
VLC Carriers are earning 100,000 PER DAY will be watching for market choke points in energy transportations
Updating as prices continue to fall. The global growth narrative seems to be over-shadowing geo-political tensions
Oil price volatility is very high.
PMI falling, EIA and similar agencies has been revising their demand estimates down by approximately 30% i.e. weak demand. My 5% estimate, is weighted with the crowd.
Revised forecast after recent reports and Brent crude price
Only  a Local war will create this level of oil price.

global growth concerns are driving oil prices more than conflict and the markets seem to be ignoring any geo-political risk premium in the Middle East (see link for ICE Dec futures below).  https://www.theice.com/products/219/Brent-Crude-Futures/data?marketId=220838&span=1 Surging oil prices now seem to be an outcome of either a full-on armed conflict in Saudi Arabia or Iran, a full trade deal with China and now the EU, and significant easing by global Central Banks (especially the Fed). It appears that more than one of these scenarios may be required to break the quagmire.
Global economic slowdown is starting to kick in while Russia and Saudis will continue to pump oil into the market. The outlook for Brent is not bullish for the remainder of this year.

Over the past 5 years, there has only been <45 days in which Brent crude oil registered a price above $75. Due to the uncertainty of global economic growth and barring any significant terrorist attacks, demand is unlikely to spike.

Normally I would have expected the Saud Refinery attack to have driven up the price about ten bucks. However the rally was two days and volatility has returned to lows. EIA says that U.S. exports of refined goods is way up - and that is after losing capacity in the Philadelphia fire. That was at the largst refinery in the nation and its still not repaired. The Sauds use a Modular plug in system for a robust repairable pipe works.
HOWEVER the Red Chinese have been tying up every tanker charter it can find and anchoring them offshore as floating storage and causing tanker rates to soar, so there may be additional volitility if China tries to corner the energy transportation market.

2.  US data worsen.

Lowering forecast from 10 to 5 due to falling oil prices over the past two weeks. The percentage increase in price required to reach 75% is now much higher.

Revising downward for now, in light of update on this week's oil prices: https://www.marketwatch.com/story/oil-lower-after-saudi-arabia-reportedly-moves-to-impose-partial-yemen-cease-fire-2019-09-27

Oil price has only been above 75 for 1 in the last 5 years, with a bump in 2018 that didn't quite get there. Base chance of 20% then. Countries producing oil have potential to produce more, and are motivated to manage price. Significant attack in Saudi Arabia failed to drive the price up to 75, and prices usually cheaper in winter. Therefore modified down to 12% - only likely in the event of a very significant crisis in one country.

As pressure on Iran increases, pressures on Saudi oil production from Iran will increase.  Trump is getting more vulnerable, opening a way for Iran to extract concessions from Trump in response to Iranian pressure.

Slight adjustment downward for now, attempting to balance reported Saudi oil infrastructure rebuilding concerns (ref.: https://www.wsj.com/articles/aramcos-repairs-could-take-months-longer-than-company-anticipates-contractors-say-11569180194),  with reported "..expectations of lower demand due to a weakening global economy..". I'm seeing upward pressure from the sanctions on carriers trading in snctioned oil with China and the growing fleet of tanker as storage preparing for the Oct 1st change in fuel standards for shipping.
Conflicts with Iran, its proxies and Saudi Arabia will continue as long as Iran is being squeezed financially

The price of crude rising above $75 relies on a conflict between Saudi Arabia and Iran. Unlikely due to the economic impact on Saudi Arabia a conflict will have due to the control Iran has over the strait of Hormuz.

Taking a view of the demand side factors first - probability of global recession is increasing, some reports suggest it is the highest its been since 2009, beating the previous "recession likelihood" peaks in 2011 and 2012. This implies lower overall global demand for energy consumption. Additionally, environmental concerns seem to be gaining traction (while this will not be a large factor, the direction of travel could weigh on oil price sentiment). Supply side factors:
Saudi supply to come back online soon, price not above USD 75 even when assumption was production output was to be 60% lower.
Fracking has vastly increased supply. US has become pretty much self-sufficient on oil due to fracking. 
OPEC has failed to coordinate to control supply. Historic factors: Since oil price collapse in 2014, oil price has closed a month above 75 USD on 10% of occasions.  Very low probability, but the price is driven by sentiment, not an explicit demand/supply mismatch. Unforseeable natural/geopolitical events could see a sharp spike in reactive sentiment causing a short term close above 75 USD.
Saudi production issues generally related to refined products.  Attacks do not appear to have created a shortage of crude, although the price may fall, in part due to reduction in refining capacity.

Predictions for Saudi Arabia and Iran conflict suggest that there is low probability of another attack on Saudi Arabian Oil production. Likewise the release of the British oil tanker makes it seem highly probable that tensions in the Middle East will diffuse. Current oil prices are at $62.42 and future contracts are trading at similar prices for two and three months out, which suggest that the market is not expect the price of oil to rise rapidly. [1] Saudi Arabian production seems to have gotten back to it's usual levels pretty quickly. So, it seems at this point that a rapid rise in price would be an unlikely occurrence.  [1] https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/energy/crude-oil/brent-crude-oil_quotes_settlements_futures.html

**I am writing this after the market close on Wednesday, September 25. Brent closed today at $62.42.** There are 51 trading days between now and December 6. In order to determine the base rate, I pulled all closing prices for Brent for the last 20 years (actually, almost 20 years--I went back to January 2000). We have 4,928 unique data points of closing prices followed by 50 additional closing prices (I used 50 instead of 51 because I went with a round number and I thought I might be writing this tomorrow). In 900 of those, or 18.3%, was there at least one closing price greater than 20.2% higher than the original closing price in the next 50 trading days. 20.2% is how much brent would have to rise in order to close above $75. So the only question now is whether we should use any number different than the base rate. I argue that if we do, it should be pretty close to the base rate given that the oil market is a pretty deep and motivated crowd-sourced assessment of the value of oil, and at least theoretically, all information about the future is incorporated. Today's closing price certainly reflects all the news that has streamed out over the last 11 days regarding the attack on the Abqaiq facility in Saudi Arabia.  I will assign a probability very slightly above the the base rate for 3 reasons: (1) In spite of the lackluster price action in brent oil since the attack, the market is showing signs of tightness, predominantly in brent time spreads. This indicates the market may be more vulnerable than normal to further supply disruptions. (2) From a geopolitical standpoint, it seems that Iran's next move would be to strike at Saudi Arabia's oil infrastructure again, a probability that may not be fully appreciated by oil market participants. Iran has previously said that if it is not free to export oil no one else in OPEC should be, and it indicated that considers the sanctions an act of war. Over the summer Iran attacked an oil tanker, shot down a US drone, and escalated its nuclear program. The attack on Abqaiq was just one incident in a pattern of aggression. Geopolitical logic would indicate that this pattern will continue until either there is a military response or Iran gets what it wants, which is a lifting of the sanctions. Since neither of the two seems likely near term, the base case next move is another incident in the pattern. (3) I acknowledge there are actually 51 trading days before the deadline, not 50 as in my base rate calculation. These three arguments are slightly offset by the current tepid level of demand for brent. The Global PMIs have been in a falling pattern throughout the last year and half or so, and much of Europe and Asia is in contraction territory. A weak economy translates into weak demand for crude oil. All else equal, it is less likely that a spike in oil prices will occur during a weak economic environment.  Thus, I assign a 19% probability, only slightly higher than my calculated base rate.

Brent oil price has not surpassed $75 once this year in 2019, In 2018 Brent oil priced dropped in Q4 and the peak price from the Saudi oil attack did not break $70. I expect close 0% with a margin of 3% for outlying factors.
Shortages are being reported globally, whether or not its propaganda doesn't matter in the short term. Threat of Iranian war is significant. Fracking issues from Dems.
Leading indicator shows crude oil bid into December. Brent has no major resistance up to $80-90.
The price didn't even hit $70 right after the Iranian attack. Unless there is another attack or a war in the area, I don't see how prices hit $75.

Adjusting from 22% on arguments here (which I had factored in to some extent already) https://www.cnbc.com/2019/09/23/rusty-braziel-to-jim-cramer-sharp-sustained-oil-price-hikes-unlikely.html "“When you look at how much resiliency that there is built into the marketplace, I think most of the market assumes that if prices go up, the U.S. and other countries will respond,” said Braziel, president and principal energy markets consultant at RBN Energy."

in the past 4 years the Q4 Brent rate has declined as often as it has increased. Of the 2 years that it increased only 1 instance was above the 15% needed to cross the $75 threshold in Q4, so the base rate for me is 25%. I'm not certain of any inclination of Iran towards escalation/deescalation so I will not adjust the base (yet) for this. Saudi Arabia has a strong disincentive to further escalation due to Aramco IPO in the near future (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-aramco-ipo-timing/saudi-aramco-ipo-unlikely-to-happen-this-year-after-oil-attacks-sources-idUSKBN1W91DA). The IPO is important for many domestic stability reasons. There are also significant reserves elsewhere globally and storage is close to capacity, so other market instability seems less worrisome. https://foreignpolicy.com/2019/09/18/the-real-reason-trump-wont-attack-iran-saudi/

From the demand side, 1% as the World is impacted by multiple economic tensions. No increase in demand is probable. From the supply side, it can be impacted by:
 - War/Conflict in the gulf, 40%/60% to conflict but only 20% it would have significant consequences for price. It is uncertain whether the US would act and after the Abqaiq and Khurais attacks, it is clear that Iran is capable to respond. A distraction from Ukraine issue is possible.
 + Iran reaches a deal with Europe (not the US) before the end of the year and starts supplying oil. While Iran is desperately in need of this agreement, I cannot see internal pressure before year end. Also, European countries have aligned with the US in blaming Iran on the attacks to the refinery/oil field. Total 21%.
The key factor here will be if Saudi Arabia (backed by the USA) goes to war with Iran. this will drive the prices up.

Global economic weakness and falling GDP projections against Middle East tensions.
Economic weakness seems more certain in the short term.

Instead of counting number of days prices had exceeded US$75, I look at the price increase that would need to bring price to US$75.  The price I'm looking at now is US$64.27.  That means an increase of 15.4% is required over the next 73 days, or 10.4 weeks. I then look at the historical distribution of weekly price changes.  I look back 10 years.  The histogram looks roughly normal and has the following stats: count    345.000000
mean    -0.000304
std         0.030611
min      -0.118000
25%     -0.015000
50%      0.000000
75%      0.015000
max      0.183000 Big assumption here: that price movements between weeks are independent.  Then mean price change over 10.4 weeks is -0.0032, and the standard deviation is 0.0977, still keeping normal distribution.  This gives probability of price increase exceeding 15.4% over next 10.4 weeks as 5.34%. Perhaps should have round up to 10% to account for crazy world now - may not be sufficient though.

Inside view

Others (thanks @Emil in [2], @JC4841in [3], @jayb in [4]) have pointed out the geopolitical uncertainties that suggest an increased probability of a price hike. Key questions that will have an influence on how this plays out, also already mentioned in the discussion:
- How long until Saudi Arabian oil production is restored to pre-drone attack levels? Will there be other attacks or events that reduce production or hinder restoring production?
- How big are the different players' oil reserves and the willingness of those sitting on them to use them to keep prices down if necessary? Crowd: 16% [1] https://www.macrotrends.net/2480/brent-crude-oil-prices-10-year-daily-chart
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/907216

Adjusting down slightly based on some research:
https://www.google.com/amp/s/oilprice.com/Energy/Crude-Oil/The-Myth-Of-Cheap-Shale-Oil.amp.html
https://www.investopedia.com/articles/active-trading/051215/cost-shale-oil-versus-conventional-oil.asp Shale oil becomes profitable around $60 a barrel and idle wells can be brought on line in about a week (https://oilandgasinfo.ca/know-fracking/how-long-does-fracking-take/). Further, with years of depressed (>$60) oil prices, I’d be curious what percent of shale oil production in the US is currently online. My guess is low, but that is unsubstantiated.  Still, though, my hypothesis is that higher prices will incentivize more US drilling which will keep prices down. Risks to this assumption are that the US might withhold oil from global markets (increase strategic reserves) or that the Permian Basin is actually running at a higher capacity than I think.

Seventy Dollars is seen as a limit, anything trading over that would be flagged, in the good ole days ppl could ride a trend, not so much now. Would think that there will be a good effort to keep prices as stable as possible, but you have to factor in any forms of external drive

Base rate: Looking at data in the five years since the steep fall of oil prices in 2014 due to slowing economic growth in the BRIC countries, the fracking boom in North America, and a failure by OPEC to enact production cuts [1]. All of these factors have relatively constant since then, which is why oil prices have been historically low. In the past 5 years (~1825 days), oil prices have exceeded $75 for ~187 days, which is ~10% of the days of this 5-year time period [2].  In the past 1 year (~365 days), oil prices have exceeded $75 for ~45 days, which is ~12% of the days of this 1-year time period. There are 77 days between today (9/20) and 12/6. The closing price only has to exceed $75 ONCE for the answer to this question to be yes. We can't extrapolate much from the 5-year or 1-year historical averages for the next 77 days since the Brent oil price each day is not independent of other days, but this does inform us that exceeding $75 is quite likely, especially if oil prices are volatile - which they are now given the recent attacks on Saudi Arabia's oil infrastructure. Analysts say that SA can mask the dramatic drop in oil production by releasing its reserves, but that if repairs take longer than ~6 weeks then oil prices are very likely to rise above $75 [3,4].  Of course, the long-term trend is slowing global growth - which lowers oil prices - but political volatility in the short-term will make-or-break this question. Given high tensions, a lot in the geopolitical realm can happen between now and 12/6 that will spook markets, which is why I'm assigning this a pretty high probability of 70%. [1] https://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/030315/why-did-oil-prices-drop-so-much-2014.asp
[2] https://www.tradingview.com/chart/?symbol=FX%3AUKOIL
[3] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-saudi-aramco-attacks-supply/real-crunch-from-saudi-arabias-oil-outage-has-yet-to-be-felt-idUSKBN1W41GL
[4] https://www.cnbc.com/2019/09/16/goldman-sachs-says-an-extended-saudi-outage-could-push-brent-crude-oil-prices-above-75.html

9/20/19 analysis article excerpt: "Friday’s price action suggests traders are building in a risk premium. This is because the Saudis are drawing on inventory, repairs are still taking place and the threat of further attacks on their oil production facilities have not been contained or eliminated.  Before the market can really become stable, Saudi inventories are going to have to return to pre-attack levels, the damaged facilities are going to have to be repaired and working at full capacity and further threats will have to be prevented...."  (Source link: https://finance.yahoo.com/news/oil-price-fundamental-daily-forecast-123857287.html. Also ref.: https://www.dailyfx.com/forex/market_alert/2019/09/17/Crude-Oil-Price-Outlook-Oil-Backwardation-Highest-in-6-Years-.html) That said: Two articles discussing lower or stable Brent price expectations written just prior to recent attacks on Saudi oil facilities (links): https://www.marketwatch.com/story/eia-lowers-its-2019-2020-wti-and-brent-oil-price-forecast-2019-09-10, https://www.reuters.com/article/us-oil-prices-poll/analysts-slash-oil-price-forecasts-due-to-fears-over-economy-trade-reuters-poll-idUSKCN1VK19J The last time Brent closed above $75/bbl was at the end of October, 2018: https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/CO1:COM (FWIW:) U.S. gasoline stocks (supplies) tend to rebuild starting around December: https://www.eia.gov/petroleum/weekly/gasoline.php December Brent crude futures presently priced at $63.33/bbl today: https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/energy/crude-oil/brent-crude-oil.html Initial forecast attempts to reflect some risk of further disruptions and/or hostile actions (-- https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/us-military-present-options-trump-iran-65738348 --) that could negatively impact oil prices in the weeks/months ahead.

~~~
Outside View
~~~ I used a Random Walk model to simulate 10,000 future scenarios based on historical frequencies of daily price movements and check in how many the price exceeds $75 on any given day in the time period. Result: 32% ~~~
Inside View
~~~ It will depend on the consequences from the attack on Saudi oil infrastructure. In particular:
- how quickly will supplies be restored? One major factor is that the US is ready to release supply from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve so that might dampen any price shocks. But the damage seems significant [1] and SA is considering increasing imports to maintain its export level.
- how will the US and Saudi Arabia respond and will this keep the oil market in a risk-on mode? The Trump administration seems to favor a peaceful approach though more is expected to be revealed after Trump is presented with options today. The Inside View skews the picture to the upside a little bit. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2019/09/20/oil-drone-attack-damage-revealed-at-saudi-aramco-facility.html

Geo-political risks are heightened and the recent supply shock pushed the markets to begin pricing it in. That being said, demand is lower in the winter months which could cause prices to fall. EIA forecast is for $61.  To set my base rate, I started in 2015 - the year that shale drilling took off in such dramatic fashion that the US achieved an unprecedented level of energy independence and an effective cap on prices was set. Since 2015, daily prices have exceeded $75 on 6% of the days. Post-Nov, 2018 might be better because that is when Trump re-instated sanctions against Iran. However, oil has not exceeded $75 in that period and was only over $74 three times.  As a result, the only factors pushing Brent prices up to seemingly unprecedented levels are a surge in global growth expectations (likely due to progress on US-China trade) or a conflict in the Middle East. Simple technical analysis (avg price this week/avg price since June) suggests a geopolitical risk premium of 10% and I think this is mostly priced in.  I put the probability of a sufficiently large conflict in the Middle East and a resolution to the trade war before December 6th at 20% and 10% respectively. That would put my probability at 28% of an increase. Various other factors such as hurricanes or other Middle East supply shocks push me up 5% to 33%.  I’ll split the difference (between 6 and 33) and go with 20% - interested to see how Iran responds to recent sanctions
